clinical_study.brief_title: Macular Hole Surgery With Temporal Inverted Internal Limiting Membrane Flap (MARTIAL)
clinical_study.official_title: Dissociated Optic Nerve Fiber Layer Appearance and Retinal Sensitivity After Macular Hole Surgery With Temporal Inverted Internal Limiting Membrane Flap Technique

brief_summary.textblock: Since 1991, idiopathic macular holes (MH) can benefit from an effective treatment initially involving pars plana vitrectomy, stripping of epiretinal membranes and intraocular gas tamponade followed by facedown positioning. The initial 58% success rate has further increased to 85-100% with internal limiting membrane (ILM) peeling. However, complete ILM removal has been shown to lead to anatomic changes causing the retina to have the appearance of a dissociated optic nerve fiber layer (DONFL). Moreover, it has been associated with decreased retinal sensitivity that may cause visual discomfort despite good visual acuity. Nawrocki et al. recently suggested to reduce the area of peeled ILM (temporal inverted ILM flap technique) in order to minimize iatrogenic trauma while maintaining satisfactory surgical outcomes. The aim of this study is to compare the incidence of DONFL appearance and retinal sensitivity after macular hole surgery in eyes that underwent temporal inverted ILM flap technique and eyes that had complete ILM peeling

primary_outcome.measure: Number of dimples on optical coherence tomography

secondary_outcome.measure: Macular hole closure rate on optical coherence tomography
Visual acuity (Logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution)
Ellipsoide zone defect on optical coherence tomography
External limiting membrane defect on optical coherence tomography

arm_group.description: The internal limiting membrane is peeled from the temporal side of the fovea only
The internal limiting membrane is completely removed around the fovea

intervention.description: Vitrectomy, temporal inverted or complete ILM peeling and gas tamponade

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients older than 18 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- Underage patients
- History of intraocular surgery (except for cataract surgery)
- Macular hole secondary to trauma, diabetic retinopathy, uveitis or associated with retinal detachment
- Concurrent macular disease (diabetic maculopathy, age-related macular degeneration)
